Mike Schwartz wrote:
> hi,
> 
> I notice that Heretrix 1.5.0 (taken from the HEAD last week) outputs 
> a down-counting demonimator in the downloaded/queued document 
> ratio.  For example I started a crawl with 2407 seeds, and it 
> initially grew as new pages were discovered, but after a few minutes 
> it reported that I was on page 568 of 593... making it hard to get a 
> sense of what the real % complete is

It's been this way for a while: URIs that were scheduled, but then
'disregarded' don't count as either pending or completed.

The most notable cause of 'disregarded' URIs is those that are
precluded by robots.txt rules -- they get scheduled, but are never
attempted, and so should neither count as successful, failed, or
still-pending.

If you've added other settings which can cause URIs to be
ignored after having been initially scheduled -- such as
narrowing the scope midcrawl, resulting in URIs that get
ruled out-of-scope on rechecking -- that will also cause
URIs to be disregarded, and the total 'queued' will decrease
without the 'completed' changing.

This area of the crawler needs improvement; the current
tallies of 'percent done' and 'estimated time remaining'
take no account of the potential for more URIs to be
discovered, and so are almost worse-than-useless.

I think tracking the effective rates of discovery versus
completion -- and the rates of change of each -- could
offer more meaningful estimates, for both the whole crawl
and individual queues. Some notes on possible approaches
are on the crawler wiki [*] here:

   http://crawler.archive.org/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?CrawlAndQueueDynamics

But, implementing some of these ideas is not yet a priority
for any upcoming releases, so it would take someone interested
in this area to contribute some code for the situation to
improve in the short term.

- Gordon @ IA

[*] Reminder: the crawler wiki edit password is available on
request to any Heritrix users/developers interested in
adding/revising the content. Email any IA team member for it.
It's only protected at all because of past problems with crude
wiki spam.
